- **Losers**: Workers in import-competing sectors may face job losses or downward pressure on wages due to increased foreign competition.

| Source | Main finding on jobs & wages | Why the result occurs |
|--------|-----------------------------|-----------------------|
| **OECD (2022) “Trade and Employment”** | Across 30 OECD economies, FTAs raise total employment by **0.3‑0.5 % per year** on average, but the effect is concentrated in **high‑skill, export‑oriented sectors**. | Trade expands markets for firms that can compete internationally; those firms tend to need more skilled labor. |
| **International Monetary Fund (IMF) “The Trade‑Wage Gap” (2021)** | FTAs increase **average real wages by 1‑2 %** after five years, driven largely by gains for workers with at least a secondary‑school education. | Higher productivity and larger export markets raise the marginal product of skilled labor. |
| **World Bank “Global Economic Prospects” (2023)** | In developing countries, FTAs raise **aggregate employment by <1 %**, but **displace workers in traditional agriculture and low‑skill manufacturing**. | Import competition squeezes low‑productivity firms; workers must move to other sectors, often requiring retraining. |
| **Autor, Dorn & Hanson, “The China Shock” (2016, updated 2020)** – often used as a natural experiment for large‑scale trade liberalisation. | Regions exposed to import competition lost **2‑5 % of manufacturing jobs** and saw **wage declines of 2‑4 %** for low‑skill workers, while high‑skill workers in the same regions saw modest wage gains. | Sudden exposure to cheaper imports forces some factories to close; the lost workers either migrate to lower‑pay jobs or exit the labor force. |

**Consensus:**  
Economic research (OECD, IMF, World Bank, major academic studies) agrees that FTAs **do not cause massive job loss across an economy**; instead they **reshape the labor market**. The average worker’s real wage tends to rise, but **the gains accrue mainly to skilled workers and to regions that can attract export‑oriented investment**. Low‑skill workers in import‑competing industries can experience job displacement and slower wage growth unless accompanied by active labour‑market policies.

## Why the common misconceptions are wrong

| Misconception | Why it’s incorrect |
|---------------|--------------------|
| “Free trade destroys all domestic jobs.” | Empirical studies repeatedly show **only modest net employment changes** (often <1 %). The majority of jobs are *reallocated* rather than eliminated. |
| “Free‑trade agreements always raise wages for everyone.” | Wage gains are **skill‑biased**. Skilled workers see the biggest increases; low‑skill workers can face stagnant or even declining wages if they remain in sectors hit by import competition. |
| “If a country signs an FTA, wages will instantly jump.” | The effects are **gradual** (typically 3‑5 years) as firms adjust production, invest, and workers acquire new skills. Immediate spikes are not observed in the data. |
| “Only developing countries suffer from FTAs.” | Both developed and developing economies experience **sectoral shifts**; the direction of the shift depends on comparative advantage, not on a country’s income level. |
